content.question: Which of the following events that preceded the outbreak of the First World War best explains why Russian troops were being mobilized against Austria-Hungary, as stated in the first paragraph?

choices.label: Russia wanted to demonstrate to Austria-Hungary that its military forces had recovered from their defeat during the Russo-Japanese War of 1904–1905.
Russia was confident that its mutual defense treaties with France and Great Britain would ensure that Austria-Hungary would not dare attack it.
Russia was acting in support of Serbia, which was facing an imminent Austro-Hungarian attack following the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand.
Russia wanted to divert its people’s attention away from its pressing economic problems and stop the growth of socialist parties.

content.answer: Russia was acting in support of Serbia, which was facing an imminent Austro-Hungarian attack following the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand.

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Explain a historical concept, development, or process.
